citation.article-title: Aurantimonas coralicida gen. nov., sp. nov., the causative agent of white plague type II on Caribbean scleractinian corals.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Aurantimonas (Au.ran.ti.mo′nas. M.L. adj. aurantiaca orange-coloured; Gr. fem. n. monas a unit; N.L. fem. n. Aurantimonas orange-coloured unicellular organism).
Intracellular pigments (carotenoids) are produced; the visible absorption spectrum of the pigment (methanol extract) shows peaks at λmax 447 and 470–471 nm and a slight inflexion at 424–427 nm.
Sole respiratory lipoquinones present are ubiquinones, with Q-10 predominating; Q-9 may account for about 1 % of the total.
The main cellular polyamine is sym-homospermidine; minor amounts of putrescine and spermidine are present.
Major polar lipids are PE, PG and PC.
DPG, PME and PDE are present as secondary components.
The predominant fatty acid is C18 : 1ω7c, along with C19 : 0 cyclo ω8c and C16 : 0.
Other fatty acids are C17 : 0, C18 : 0, C16 : 1ω7c and C20 : 1ω7c.
The sole hydroxylated fatty acid is C18 : 1 2-OH.
The G+C content of the DNA of the type species is 66·3 mol% (by HPLC).
The type species is Aurantimonas coralicida.
